Page.title: source category trend
Page.description: This is the text that goes in the meta description tag
Page._content:
# Income Over Time
The chart below displays trends in government income over time. From the chart below, it looks like income generated from tax revenue has grown. Does this mean you've been paying more? Not necessarily. What this chart shows is that economic growth has been on the rise. The U.S. economy has been growing steadily since 2013. As we previously learned in the sections above, taxes are a percent of income for people and businesses. If an economy is performing well, people and businesses earn more, and income generated from taxes increase.
## Receipts by Source Categories
Click a category name to explore subcategories

Page.title: receipts
Page.description: This is the text that goes in the meta description tag
Page._content:
# In 2017, the government collected $3.4 trillion.
Each dot in the chart represents $1 billion. Each dot represents contributions by you, your family, your neighbors, your place of business, and the various corporations you deal with every day. For context, $3.3 trillion divided by the U.S. population in 2017 (326.4 million), is equivalent to a little more than $10,000 for every individual counted in the 2017 U.S. Census.
Gross Domestic Product measures the size of the Nation's economy in terms of the total value of all goods and services that are produced in a year. Considering financial results relative to the GDP is an indicator of the economy's capacity to sustain the government's many programs.
In FY 2017, the total GDP of the U.S. was $19.4 trillion.
Total government revenue made up roughly 17.4 percent of the GDP.

Page.content:
In 2017, the government collected $3.4 trillion.

Each dot in the chart represents $1 billion. Each dot represents contributions by you, your family, your neighbors, your place of business, and the various corporations you deal with every day.

For context, $3.3 trillion divided by the U.S. population in 2017 (326.4 million), is equivalent to a little more than $10,000 for every individual counted in the 2017 U.S. Census.
Gross Domestic Product measures the size of the Nation’s economy in terms of the total value of all goods and services that are produced in a year. Considering financial results relative to the GDP is an indicator of the economy’s capacity to sustain the government’s many programs.
In FY 2017, the total GDP of the U.S. was $19.4 trillion.
Total government revenue made up roughly 17.4 percent of the GDP.
Page.more:
In 2017, the government collected $3.4 trillion.

Each dot in the chart represents $1 billion. Each dot represents contributions by you, your family, your neighbors, your place of business, and the various corporations you deal with every day.

For context, $3.3 trillion divided by the U.S. population in 2017 (326.4 million), is equivalent to a little more than $10,000 for every individual counted in the 2017 U.S. Census.
Gross Domestic Product measures the size of the Nation’s economy in terms of the total value of all goods and services that are produced in a year. Considering financial results relative to the GDP is an indicator of the economy’s capacity to sustain the government’s many programs.
In FY 2017, the total GDP of the U.S. was $19.4 trillion.
Total government revenue made up roughly 17.4 percent of the GDP.
